top_categories.workout_context: Fairfield Harvest Rush rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Fairfield Harvest Rush’s iowa rolling, local event demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Fairfield Harvest Rush. Make this intensity feel like home.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Fairfield Harvest Rush when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Racing Fairfield Harvest Rush isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Fairfield Harvest Rush’s iowa rolling gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Fairfield Harvest Rush — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Fairfield Harvest Rush’s iowa rolling gravel drains energy reserves faster than the distance suggests — durability training bridges the gap.
The Norwegian double-threshold method builds the sustained power base for Fairfield Harvest Rush — massive training stimulus without the recovery cost of VO2max work.
The varied gradients at Fairfield Harvest Rush reward climbing adaptability — knowing when to sit, when to stand, and when to switch.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Fairfield Harvest Rush — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on iowa rolling gravel.
Cadence efficiency makes every pedal stroke at Fairfield Harvest Rush count — smooth technique reduces muscular fatigue over long distances.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Fairfield Harvest Rush’s 55 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Fairfield Harvest Rush requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on iowa rolling gravel to build confidence. Expect: iowa rolling, local event, midwest gravel.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and G Spot to prepare you for 55 miles of iowa rolling gravel in Fairfield, Iowa.
